title: Bev Priestman
text:
Beverly Priestman (born 29 April 1986) is an English professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager who is the current head coach of the <a href="Canada%20women%27s%20national%20soccer%20team">Canada women's national team</a>.
Early life.
At age 12, Priestman signed-up for <a href="futsal">futsal</a> in Consett, under <a href="John%20Herdman">John Herdman</a>, who was at the time a university lecturer and a part-time football coach. Priestman graduated from <a href="Liverpool%20John%20Moores%20University">Liverpool John Moores University</a> and worked for <a href="Everton%20F.C.%20%28women%29">Everton</a> under <a href="Mo%20Morley">Mo Morley</a>.
Coaching career.
Early career.
Priestman has coached Canada's <a href="Canada%20women%27s%20national%20under-17%20soccer%20team">U-17</a> and <a href="Canada%20women%27s%20national%20under-20%20soccer%20team">U-20</a> women's squads and was assistant coach for the <a href="Canada%20women%27s%20national%20soccer%20team">Canada women's national soccer team</a> under head coach Herdman. She coached <a href="England%20women%27s%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">England's women's U-17 squad</a>, and she was assistant coach of the <a href="England%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">England women's national football team</a> under head coach <a href="Phil%20Neville">Phil Neville</a> from 2018 to 2020.
Canada women.
In October 2020, Priestman was appointed as the head coach of <a href="Canada%20women%27s%20national%20soccer%20team">Canada women's national soccer team</a>, leading them to the Gold Medal in the Tokyo Olympics on August 6, 2021.
Personal life.
Priestman is married to <a href="Emma%20Humphries">Emma Humphries</a>, a former midfielder with the <a href="New%20Zealand%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">New Zealand football team</a>. Their son Jack was born in 2018.
